discussion.content: The purpose of the sticky keys feature in X (the X Window System) is to assist users who have difficulty holding down multiple keys at once. With sticky keys enabled, a user can press and release each modifier key (e.g., Shift, Control, Alt) individually, instead of having to hold down all the keys at once. This makes it easier for users with physical impairments or disabilities to perform keyboard shortcuts that require multiple keys to be pressed simultaneously.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the sticky keys feature in X?

choices.A: To assist users who have difficulty holding down multiple keys at once.
choices.C: To ignore brief keystrokes according to a specified time limit.
choices.B: To prevent repeated input of a single character if the key is held down.
choices.D: To repeat the input of a single character.

discussion.content:
asks handled by a display manager like XDM or KDM include:

User authentication: verifying the user's credentials (username and password) and logging them in to their desktop environment.

Session management: starting the desktop environment and managing the user's session.

Display configuration: configuring the display and monitor settings, such as screen resolution and color depth.

questions.question_text: Which of the following are tasks handled by a display manager like XDM or KDM? (Choose TWO correct answers.)

choices.D: Lock the screen when the user was inactive for a configurable amount of time.
choices.C: Handle the login of a user.
choices.B: Configure additional devices like new monitors or projectors when they are attached.
choices.A: Start and prepare the desktop environment for the user.

questions.question_text: On a machine running several X servers, how are the different instances of the X11 server identified?

choices.B: By a unique IPv6 address from the fe80::/64 subnet.
choices.C: By the name of the user that runs the X server like x11:bob.

discussion.content: On a machine running several X servers, the different instances of the X11 server are identified by a display name like:0, :1, :2, etc. The display name is a combination of a colon (:) followed by a number that represents the display number and screen number of the X server. The display number represents the instance of the X server and the screen number represents the number of displays attached to that server.

comments.content: The xhost program is used in X Window System to control access to an X server from other hosts. It is used to add or remove host names or user names from the list of hosts that are allowed to connect to the X server. The xhost command allows for a fine-grained control of the access permissions to an X server, which can improve security. For example, an administrator can use xhost to allow connections only from trusted hosts, or to block connections from untrusted hosts. It is important to note that the xhost security mechanism should not be relied upon as the sole security measure, as it has some limitations and is relatively easy to bypass.
